Stem: Tom uses a flashlight to look under his bed. He sees shiny spots on his bicycle reflectors. When the room light is on, the reflectors are not as noticeable. Why are the reflectors more noticeable with the flashlight?
Choices: A) The flashlight is brighter than any room light, B) The concentrated flashlight beam reflects more strongly off the reflectors compared to the scattered room light, C) The reflectors only work in the dark, D) The room light absorbs the reflector material
Scenario Justification: Real scenario with an observable phenomenon — flashlight vs room light on reflectors. Students must reason about how light concentration affects reflection visibility. Genuine puzzlement about why reflectors behave differently under different light sources.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for a light behavior phenomenon by comparing two conditions. Engages Constructing Explanations from evidence of two observations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that light reflects off surfaces and that concentrated vs scattered light sources produce different reflection effects. Applied understanding of light behavior.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — concentrated beam (cause) produces stronger visible reflection (effect) compared to diffuse room light. Students must reason causally about light behavior.
Key Recommendation: Good phenomenon-based question comparing two light conditions. Strengthen by asking a Part B about what property of reflectors causes them to redirect light back toward the source, engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: A biologist is researching desert animals and finds that many have special kidney cells that save water, light-colored body coverings, and large ears that release heat. Which pair of desert animals would most likely have these features?
Choices: A) Rabbits and foxes, B) Frogs and salamanders, C) Penguins and polar bears, D) Trout and salmon
Scenario Justification: Real biological research scenario with specific structural/functional adaptations described. Students must match adaptation profiles to appropriate desert organisms. Requires reasoning about organism-environment fit.
SEP Justification: Students apply knowledge of organism structure-function to classify which organisms fit the described adaptations. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — largely matching known organisms to described traits.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how internal structures (kidney cells) and external features (ears, covering) support survival in desert environments. Goes beyond recall to application of structure-function reasoning.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function (adaptations serve survival purposes) but students are not asked to explain why these features help — only to identify which animals have them.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario with real adaptations. Elevate by providing an unfamiliar desert animal and asking students to predict which internal structures it would need and explain why, requiring explicit Structure and Function reasoning.

Stem: Two identical tomato plants are grown under the same conditions — same soil, water, and sunlight. However, one plant produces many large tomatoes while the other produces only a few small ones. What BEST explains why the plants grew differently?
Choices: A) The sunlight was brighter on one side of the garden, B) One plant received more water than the other, C) One plant had damaged leaf veins that limited nutrient transport to the fruit, D) The soil had different amounts of minerals on each side
Scenario Justification: Strong scenario with a genuine puzzle — identical conditions but different outcomes. Eliminates environmental variables by design, forcing students to reason about internal structural differences. High uncertainty and reasoning demand.
SEP Justification: Students must analyze evidence (same external conditions, different outcomes) and construct an explanation that identifies an internal structural cause. Engages Constructing Explanations and Engaging in Argument from Evidence — students must evaluate why external explanations fail.
DCI Justification: Requires deep understanding that internal structures (leaf veins for nutrient transport) affect plant growth and fruit production. Students must connect vascular system function to observable outcomes. Synthesis-level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (damaged veins cause reduced nutrient transport, leading to smaller/fewer fruit) and Structure and Function (vein structure serves transport function). Students must reason with both CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Excellent question. The controlled-conditions setup forces students to reason beyond environmental factors to internal structural explanations. One of the strongest items on this test.

Stem: Deep-sea anglerfish live in complete darkness at the bottom of the ocean. How do their internal structures help them survive in this environment?
Choices: A) They have thick scales that reflect sunlight from the surface, B) They have large eyes that collect the dim sunlight filtering down, C) Specialized cells produce light to attract prey and a large liver stores extra energy between meals, D) They breathe air by swimming to the surface periodically
Scenario Justification: Presents a real organism in an extreme environment. Students must reason about how internal structures solve specific survival challenges (no light, scarce food). Genuine scientific reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation connecting internal structures to survival functions in a specific environment. Engages Constructing Explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how specialized internal structures (bioluminescent cells, liver for energy storage) support survival. Deep application of structure-function at the organ/cellular level. Goes well beyond recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function directly — specialized cells produce light (structure serves function) and large liver stores energy (structure serves function). Students reason with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Strong structure-function question with real organism context. Could elevate by asking students to predict what would happen if the light-producing cells stopped functioning, requiring causal reasoning about survival consequences.

Stem: Desert mice have large ears, specialized kidneys, and dig underground burrows. How do these features work together to help the mice survive in the desert?
Choices: A) Large ears help them hear predators and kidneys digest food while burrows store food, B) Large ears collect rainwater and kidneys filter sand while burrows trap cool air, C) Large ears attract mates and kidneys produce energy while burrows protect eggs, D) Ears release excess body heat and kidneys conserve water while burrows provide shelter from the sun
Scenario Justification: Real scenario with multiple adaptations that students must explain as an integrated system. The question asks how features work together — requiring systems-level reasoning rather than isolated trait identification.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation that integrates multiple structural features into a coherent survival strategy. Engages Constructing Explanations with a systems perspective.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how multiple internal and external structures serve complementary survival functions. Students must connect each feature to a specific desert challenge (heat, water scarcity, sun exposure).
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models — features work together as an integrated system for survival. Also engages Structure and Function for each individual adaptation. Students must reason with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Good systems-level question about integrated adaptations. Strengthen by asking students to predict which adaptation would be MOST critical if the desert became even hotter, requiring prioritization and deeper causal reasoning.

Stem: A dog walking with its owner stops near a bakery. The owner cannot smell anything from outside, but the dog is excited. How does the dog know about the baked goods inside?
Choices: A) The dog can see the baked goods through the window using its sharp eyes, B) Scent molecules from the baked goods travel through the air into the dog's nose and are processed by the brain through nerve signals, C) The dog hears the sounds of baking and associates them with food, D) The dog feels vibrations from the oven through the sidewalk
Scenario Justification: Engaging real-world scenario with a puzzling observation — dog detects something the human cannot. Students must trace the complete sensory pathway from stimulus to brain processing.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation tracing the complete mechanism of sensory detection — molecule travel, receptor detection, and neural processing. Engages Constructing Explanations with mechanistic reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the complete sensory processing pathway: stimulus (scent molecules) → receptor (nose) → signal transmission (nerves) → processing (brain). Goes beyond simple sense identification to mechanistic understanding.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (scent molecules cause nerve signals which cause brain processing) as a causal chain. Also touches Systems and System Models (nervous system as information processing system).
Key Recommendation: Good question requiring mechanistic reasoning about sensory processing. Elevate by asking Part B: Why can the dog detect the scent but the owner cannot? — requiring comparison of sensory structure differences.

Stem: A geologist found four rock layers at a cliff site. From bottom to top: Layer 1 contains coral and marine shells; Layer 2 contains fish fossils and sand; Layer 3 contains fern fossils and coal deposits; Layer 4 contains land animal bones and petrified trees. How did the environment change over time?
Choices: A) Forest → wetland → shallow water → deep ocean, B) Deep ocean → shallow water → wetland → forest land, C) Shallow water → deep ocean → forest → wetland, D) Wetland → forest → deep ocean → shallow water
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario with specific fossil and sediment evidence across four distinct layers. Students must connect each fossil assemblage to an environment AND apply superposition to sequence the changes. Multi-step reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze multiple lines of fossil evidence, apply superposition, and construct a chronological explanation of environmental change. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Constructing Explanations from Evidence. High practice demand.
DCI Justification: Requires deep understanding of both superposition (bottom = oldest) and fossils as indicators of past environments. Four-layer complexity exceeds typical two-layer questions. Synthesis-level application.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (systematic environmental change over time revealed by fossil patterns in layers) and Stability and Change (environment transitions from one state to another). Students reason with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Excellent multi-layered question requiring integration of superposition with fossil evidence interpretation. The four-layer complexity with distinct fossil assemblages creates genuine analytical demand. One of the best items on this test.

Stem: Two marble statues were made at the same time from the same type of marble. One was placed in the open for 10 years and now looks rough and pitted. The other was kept under a roof and remains smooth. Why does the outdoor statue look different?
Choices: A) Sunlight bleached the marble and caused it to crack, B) Wind carved decorative patterns into the marble surface, C) Temperature changes caused the marble to expand and shrink repeatedly, D) Rain water slowly dissolved the marble surface over time and carried away particles
Scenario Justification: Strong comparative scenario with controlled variables — same marble, same age, different exposure. Students must identify chemical weathering as the cause by reasoning about the key difference (rain exposure). Genuine analytical reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students analyze a natural experiment (two conditions, one variable) and construct an explanation for the observed difference. Engages Constructing Explanations from comparative evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding chemical weathering — that water dissolves rock surfaces over time. Students must connect rain exposure to surface degradation. Applied understanding of Earth surface processes.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect — rain water (cause) dissolves marble (effect) over time. Also engages Stability and Change — marble appeared stable but changed slowly. Students reason causally.
Key Recommendation: Strong comparative design that isolates the weathering variable. Could elevate by asking students to predict what the outdoor statue would look like after 50 years and explain their reasoning using patterns of change over time.

Stem: Two rock formations are studied. Formation A is on a hilltop exposed to wind and has noticeably more loose sediment around it. Formation B is in a valley near a stream and has less loose sediment. Why does Formation A have more sediment around its base?
Choices: A) Wind erosion continuously removes particles from Formation A and deposits them nearby, B) The stream near Formation B carries all sediment away while Formation A's sediment stays, C) Formation A is made of softer rock that crumbles naturally, D) Animals on the hilltop dig into the rock and create sediment
Scenario Justification: Comparative scenario with two formations in different settings. Students must reason about why a hilltop formation has MORE sediment despite being exposed — wind breaks particles off but deposits them locally. Some reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze comparative evidence from two locations and construct an explanation for the difference. Engages Constructing Explanations from observational evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding wind erosion processes — how wind mechanically removes rock particles. Students must connect wind exposure on hilltops to erosion and local deposition.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (wind causes particle removal and deposition) but the causal reasoning is fairly direct. Does not deeply engage other CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Good comparative erosion question. Strengthen by providing data about wind speed at different elevations and particle sizes at each formation, asking students to identify the pattern and explain the relationship.

Stem: A topographic map shows a hill. The contour lines on the east side are very close together while the contour lines on the west side are far apart. What does this pattern show about the hill?
Image/Diagram Description: Topographic map showing contour lines close together on east side and far apart on west side
Choices: A) The east side has more vegetation than the west side, B) The east side is steeper than the west side, C) The west side is higher in elevation than the east side, D) The east side receives more rainfall than the west side
Scenario Justification: Students must interpret a topographic map convention — close contour lines indicate steep slopes. Requires understanding of map representation of terrain. Visual-spatial reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret data from a topographic map to draw a conclusion about terrain. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from a scientific representation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that contour line spacing represents slope steepness — a key map-reading skill aligned with Earth science content. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize the pattern (close lines = steep) and apply it. Also engages Scale and Proportion — contour intervals represent proportional elevation changes.
Key Recommendation: Good map interpretation question. Could elevate by providing actual elevation data at specific points and asking students to calculate slope differences between the two sides.

Stem: Use the topographic map to answer: What is the elevation at line C?
Image/Diagram Description: Topographic map with labeled contour lines and a contour interval; line C is at a specific position
Scenario Justification: Image-dependent map reading question. Students must count contour intervals to determine elevation at a marked line. Requires procedural application rather than conceptual reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students read and interpret a topographic map at a procedural level — counting contour intervals. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data but at a low level (data reading rather than interpretation).
DCI Justification: Tests ability to read contour lines and apply contour intervals. Procedural skill rather than deep Earth science understanding.
CCC Justification: Engages Scale and Proportion (contour interval represents consistent elevation change) at a basic level. Patterns implicitly engaged in counting intervals.
Key Recommendation: Procedural map reading question. Without the image, evaluation is limited. Elevate by asking students to use the contour data to describe the terrain between two points and predict water flow direction.

Stem: A coastal town is considering three options to reduce erosion damage: (1) Sea walls costing $2 million with a 30-year lifespan, (2) Beach replenishment costing $500K every 3-5 years, and (3) Artificial reefs with a 50+ year lifespan. The town has limited funds and needs protection for the next 50 years. Which combination would best meet their needs?
Choices: A) Beach replenishment and artificial reefs, B) Sea walls and beach replenishment, C) Sea walls and artificial reefs, D) All three options together
Scenario Justification: Strong engineering design problem with real constraints (limited budget, 50-year timeframe) and quantitative data (costs, lifespans). Students must evaluate trade-offs between multiple solutions and optimize for constraints. Genuine decision-making required.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing design solutions against criteria and constraints using quantitative data. Engages Designing Solutions and Engaging in Argument from Evidence. High practice demand — students must justify why one combination is better than others.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design principles — evaluating trade-offs, considering long-term costs, and matching solutions to constraints. Applied at decision-making level.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models (coastal protection as a system with interacting components) and Cause and Effect (each solution has different causal mechanisms and cost implications over time).
Key Recommendation: Excellent engineering design question with authentic constraints and quantitative reasoning. Students must integrate cost, lifespan, and budget data to optimize a solution. Among the strongest items on this test.

Stem: A mountain community needs to prevent landslides. Method P: Retaining wall — takes 6 months to build, high cost, holds 1000 tons, lasts 30 years, no resident action needed. Method Q: Reinforced soil slopes — takes 2 months to build, moderate cost, holds 500 tons, lasts 10 years, requires regular resident monitoring. The community prioritizes long-term reliability and minimal resident involvement. Which method should they choose and why?
Choices: A) Method Q because it is cheaper and faster to build, B) Method Q because residents can monitor it themselves, C) Method P because it has greater capacity and requires no resident action, D) Method P because it takes longer to build so it must be better
Scenario Justification: Excellent engineering design comparison with explicit criteria and constraints presented in a data-rich format. Students must weigh multiple factors against stated priorities. Genuine trade-off analysis required.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate two design solutions against explicit criteria (long-term reliability, minimal resident involvement) using provided data. Engages Evaluating Competing Design Solutions and Engaging in Argument from Evidence. High practice demand.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design process — matching solutions to criteria and constraints. Students must prioritize specified criteria over attractive but irrelevant features (cost, speed).
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (design choices cause different outcomes over time) and Systems and System Models (the solution must function within community constraints). Students reason with multiple CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Outstanding engineering design comparison. The explicit priority criteria force students to reason beyond simple cost/speed comparisons. The distractor options test whether students can resist attractive but irrelevant features.

Stem: Two skateboarders of equal mass ride down the same hill. Alex travels 24 meters in 8 seconds. Jamie travels 24 meters in 6 seconds. Compare their energies.
Choices: A) Alex had more energy because he took more time to travel the same distance, B) They had the same energy because they traveled the same distance, C) Alex had more energy because slower objects store more energy, D) Jamie had more energy because she traveled at a higher speed of 4 m/s
Scenario Justification: Quantitative scenario with controlled variables (same mass, same distance) and different times. Students must calculate or reason about speed and connect it to kinetic energy. Multi-step reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students analyze quantitative data (distance, time) to compare speeds and connect speed to energy. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Using Mathematics. Multi-step reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the relationship between speed and kinetic energy — faster objects have more kinetic energy. Students must also reason about speed = distance/time. Application-level with quantitative component.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter (kinetic energy depends on speed) and Patterns (systematic relationship between speed and energy). Students must use quantitative patterns in reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Good quantitative energy comparison. Could strengthen by asking Part B: If a third skateboarder with twice the mass traveled at the same speed as Jamie, how would their energy compare? — extending to mass-energy relationship.

Stem: Two identical glass jars are placed on a counter. One contains hot water at 60 degrees C and the other contains room temperature water at 20 degrees C. What will happen to the energy in the jars after one hour?
Choices: A) Heat flows from the cooler jar to the warmer jar until both are the same temperature, B) Heat flows from the warmer jar to the cooler jar and from both jars to the room until all reach room temperature, C) Both jars stay at their original temperatures because glass insulates the water, D) The hot jar gets hotter and the cold jar gets colder over time
Scenario Justification: Real scenario with two objects at different temperatures in a room. Students must reason about heat transfer in multiple directions — not just jar-to-jar but also jars-to-room. Multi-directional energy flow reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for thermal energy transfer in a system with three components (hot jar, cool jar, room). Engages Constructing Explanations with systems-level reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that heat flows from warmer to cooler AND that all objects in a system eventually reach thermal equilibrium with their surroundings. Goes beyond simple hot-to-cold transfer.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter (heat energy flows from warmer to cooler regions) and Systems and System Models (the jars and room form a thermal system moving toward equilibrium). Students reason with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Strong thermal energy question requiring multi-directional heat flow reasoning. The three-component system (hot jar, cool jar, room) elevates beyond typical two-object heat transfer questions.

Stem: Sarah is making hot chocolate using an electric kettle. She plugs in the kettle, turns it on, and watches the water heat up. Which observation shows that electrical energy is being converted to heat energy?
Choices: A) The power cord feels warm to the touch, B) The kettle makes a humming sound when turned on, C) Bubbles begin rising from the bottom of the water to the top, D) The indicator light on the kettle turns on
Scenario Justification: Real scenario about energy transformation. Students must distinguish between multiple observations and identify which one provides evidence of electrical-to-heat conversion. Requires evaluating evidence quality.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple observations to identify which one serves as evidence for a specific energy transformation. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — distinguishing relevant from irrelevant evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding energy conversion (electrical to heat) and recognizing that bubbling water indicates heating from below. Students must connect an observable phenomenon to an energy process.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (electrical energy causes water to heat, causing convection bubbles) but the causal chain reasoning is not deeply required — students mainly identify the correct observation.
Key Recommendation: Good evidence-evaluation question. The multiple plausible observations create genuine reasoning demand. Strengthen by asking students to explain WHY bubbling indicates heat energy specifically, requiring mechanistic explanation.

Stem: Sam builds a simple circuit. When he uses copper wire, the light bulb turns on. When he replaces the copper wire with a wooden stick of the same size, the bulb does not light. Why?
Choices: A) The wooden stick is too thick for electricity to pass through, B) The light bulb was broken when the wooden stick was used, C) Copper wire creates its own electricity while wood does not, D) Copper allows electrical current to flow through it while wood blocks the flow of current
Scenario Justification: Comparative investigation scenario — same circuit, different materials, different outcomes. Students must reason about conductors and insulators from experimental evidence.
SEP Justification: Students analyze results from a comparative test and construct an explanation for the different outcomes. Engages Constructing Explanations and Planning and Carrying Out Investigations (understanding fair test design).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding electrical conductivity — that materials differ in their ability to conduct electricity. Students must connect material properties to circuit function. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (material property causes circuit to work or not) at a basic level. Structure and Function (material structure determines electrical function) is implicit but not deeply engaged.
Key Recommendation: Good comparative investigation question. Elevate by providing a data table of multiple materials (metal, rubber, glass, aluminum foil) tested in the circuit and asking students to identify the pattern and classify materials as conductors or insulators.

Stem: A student builds a wind-powered generator using a pinwheel connected to a small LED light. When the pinwheel is not connected to the LED, it spins quickly in the wind. When connected to the LED and the LED lights up, the pinwheel spins more slowly. Why does the pinwheel slow down?
Choices: A) Some of the wind energy is being converted to electrical energy to power the LED, leaving less energy available for spinning, B) The LED light is too heavy and weighs down the pinwheel, C) The wind loses power when it hits the LED light, D) The pinwheel is defective and needs to be replaced
Scenario Justification: Excellent scenario presenting a counterintuitive observation — connecting a load slows the generator. Students must reason about energy conservation and transformation. Genuine puzzlement with deep reasoning demand.
SEP Justification: Students construct a mechanistic explanation for an unexpected observation using energy conservation principles. Engages Constructing Explanations with deep causal-mechanistic reasoning. High practice demand.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding energy conservation — energy cannot be created, so the electrical energy powering the LED must come from the kinetic energy of the pinwheel. Deep application of energy transformation concepts.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Energy and Matter — energy is conserved and transformed, so energy going to the LED means less energy for spinning. Students must reason about energy budgets within a system.
Key Recommendation: Outstanding question. The counterintuitive observation (connecting a load slows the source) requires genuine energy conservation reasoning. Students must think about energy budgets — one of the strongest items on this test.

Stem: An electric motor powers a small water fountain in a garden. What energy transformations occur in this system?
Choices: A) Heat energy transforms into light energy which moves the water, B) Electrical energy transforms into motion energy which moves the water upward, C) Sound energy transforms into electrical energy which pushes the water, D) Light energy transforms into heat energy which boils the water upward
Scenario Justification: Simple energy transformation identification in a familiar device. Students must trace the energy conversion chain but the reasoning is fairly straightforward.
SEP Justification: Students identify energy transformations in a device. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — tracing a known energy conversion sequence.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of electrical-to-mechanical energy conversion. Basic application of energy transformation concepts. Lower complexity than Q18.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter (energy transformation chain) at a basic level. Students identify but don't deeply reason with the CCC.
Key Recommendation: Basic energy transformation identification. After the strong Q18, this feels redundant and simpler. Redesign to ask students to trace multiple energy transformations in a more complex system and identify where energy is lost as heat.

Stem: A coastal town is planning how to generate electricity. They want the option that is LEAST harmful to the marine ecosystem and air quality. Which option should they choose?
Choices: A) Building a coal-fired power plant near the coast, B) Using geothermal heating from underground heat sources, C) Constructing an offshore oil drilling platform, D) Building a natural gas plant near the harbor
Scenario Justification: Real decision-making scenario about energy choices with environmental constraints. Students must evaluate multiple options against environmental impact criteria.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate options against criteria (marine ecosystem harm, air quality). Engages Evaluating Competing Solutions at a basic level — but the correct answer is fairly obvious once students know geothermal basics.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding different energy sources and their environmental impacts. Students must compare fossil fuels to geothermal energy across two criteria (marine and air). Application-level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (different energy sources cause different environmental effects) at a basic level. Systems thinking about environmental impacts is implicit.
Key Recommendation: Good real-world context but the correct answer is fairly obvious — geothermal clearly beats three fossil fuel options. Strengthen by including solar and wind as additional options, making the comparison genuinely require weighing trade-offs.

Stem: A student creates two waves by shaking two ropes. Wave A has tall peaks that are far apart. Wave B has short peaks that are close together. What do these observations tell us about the two waves?
Choices: A) Wave A has greater amplitude than Wave B, B) Wave B has greater amplitude than Wave A, C) Both waves have the same amplitude but different colors, D) Wave A has a shorter wavelength than Wave B
Scenario Justification: Direct observation-to-property matching. Students must connect 'tall peaks' to amplitude and 'far apart' to wavelength. Largely definitional application.
SEP Justification: Students interpret observations of wave properties. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic level — matching visual descriptions to wave property terms.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of wave properties (amplitude, wavelength) and their visual representations. Definitional-level application.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (wave properties form observable patterns) at a basic level but students are not deeply reasoning with the CCC.
Key Recommendation: Basic wave property identification. Redesign by providing wave diagrams with measurements and asking students to predict how changing amplitude affects energy transfer, connecting wave properties to energy concepts.

Stem: Construction on a hillside is causing soil to wash into a nearby lake. Which action would BEST reduce the impact on the lake while maintaining the natural environment?
Choices: A) Paving the hillside with concrete to prevent soil movement, B) Building a large wall between the hillside and the lake, C) Planting deep-rooted native trees and shrubs on the hillside, D) Diverting the lake water to a different location
Scenario Justification: Real environmental problem requiring students to evaluate solutions that balance erosion prevention with maintaining the natural environment. Dual-constraint reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple solutions against two criteria (reduce erosion impact AND maintain natural environment). Engages Evaluating Competing Design Solutions and Constructing Explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that plant roots stabilize soil (bioengineering solution) and that concrete/walls are artificial interventions. Students must connect biological function to erosion prevention.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (plant roots cause soil stabilization, reducing erosion) and Structure and Function (deep root structure serves an anchoring function). Also engages Systems thinking — solution must work within the natural system.
Key Recommendation: Good dual-constraint question balancing erosion control with environmental preservation. Strengthen by providing data about different plant species' root depths and erosion reduction rates, asking students to select the best species and justify with evidence.
